g.text: • supports the token exchange extension of OAuth2
• publishes its metadata on a URL /.well-known/oauth-authorization-server
• also acts as RqP's Identity Provider
• is registered at AS-RqP as a public or confidential client
• acts as a Relying Party in a RqP's Identity Provider in order to obtain an an access_token_with_user_claims
• should be registered at AS-RO as a public or confidential client; in case of immediate access,
the client does not have to be registered at AS-RO
RO has set up RS and registers his 'RS API' resource at AS-RO
1. Request 'RS API' resource with no access token
AS-RO generates the permission ticket itself (ticket is a random NONCE) and the permission token,
which is bound to the permission ticket through a permission ticket hash.
The permission token contains these claims:
issuer is the URI that identifies who issues the permission token
ts is the timestamp of when the permission ticket was created
audience is the URI that identifies the resource server
3. Return the permission ticket and the permission token
4. Return 401 with the permission ticket and the permission token
5. Request a claims token (token exchange request)
AS-RqP generates the claim token, which contains these claims:
4. bootstrap discovery of AS-RqP config url from email address via WebFinger;
if this doesn't work, build well-known url using domain part of email_address
